Caption: Figure 1: Base 10 prefix routing in Tapestry from 5230 to 8954.
Mention:
objects are assigned unique identifiers called keys from
the same space.
Each key is dynamically mapped by the overlay to a
unique live node, called its root node. While a key’s root
can change with network membership, a single node is
responsible for a key in a consistent network at any given
time. To deliver a message to its root node (key-based
routing), each node forwards messages using a locally
maintained routing table of overlay links. Figure 1 shows
an example of Tapestry’s prefix routing algorithm, and
Figure 2 shows a node’s routing table.
Each system defines a function that maps keys to nodes.
For example, keys can be mapped to the live node with
the closest nodeId as in Pastry [8], or the closest nodeId
clockwise from the key as in Chord [14].
